description.narrative:
3S Rivers Protection Network (3SPN) is a Cambodian local civil society organisation, which was founded in Banlung Town, Ratanakiri Province in 2001 (as the Sesan Protection Network) and registered with the Ministry of Interior (as 3SPN) in 2005. The network was founded in order to assist dam-affected communities living alongside the Sesan River in Cambodia after serious impacts occurred alongthe river caused by the hydropower dam construction upstream in Vietnam. The 3S network has since expanded its activities due to requests from villagers to cover and assist all villages situated along the Sesan and Srepok Rivers and works with partner organisations to assist communities living along the Sekong River. 3SPN derives its name from the 3S tributaries to the Mekong River in North-East Cambodia (Sesan, Srepok and Sekong rivers).
3SPN developed its own three-year strategic plan (2013-2015) with the focus on fourultimate goals include Hydropower Advocacy, Community-Based Organizations development, information sharing and continue effective management and governance of the institution.
Oxfam Novib has started its support to 3SPN in 2013, the first year of 3SPN# three-year strategic plan implementation, with the budget of EUR 50,000 together with OAU.For 2014, it is clear that OAU will consider supporting 3SPN only in mid-2014 for the alignment to the OAU#s fiscal year (Jul 2014-Jun 2015). OAU plan to have long term support and partnership with 3SPN through the upcoming four-year AusAid fund (2014-2017). So, OAU insisted that ONL shall continue its support to 3SPN for 2014 for the outstanding work of Oxfam on water governance.

participating-org.narrative:
In order to support dam-affected communities in North-Eastern Cambodia, the 3S Rivers Protection Network (3SPN) was formed with an ultimate goal to restore the socio-economic, environmental, and cultural situation, and the rights of indigenous communities living along the Sesan, Srepok, and Sekong rivers in Cambodia and to ensure that all national and international standard policies are fullypromoted and implemented. 3SPN is a local coordinating body in the form of a community-based organization representing approximately 31,000 indigenous people living along the 3S Rivers.
The Sesan Protection Network was originally formed in 2001 with the assistance of Oxfam America and with the initial plan to form a grassroots dam affected people's network while simultaneously increasing awareness and knowledge amongst local community members to fully understand the hydropower impacts occurring on the Sesan River and their rights as riparian people. Over the course of three years, the network worked on mobilizinga broad-base network of communities impacted by Vietnam’s upstream dams.
By 2004, the network began its second phase of work of network strengthening, in order for localcommunities to advocate for their rights and to be seen as a credible, legitimate representative body able to participate in dialogue and negotiations with key national and regional decision-makers and voice out their collective concerns. In order to achieve this, the Sesan Protection Network carried out capacity building activities,while also working to empower communities, develop a local,national and international advocacy coalition and to increase knowledge through research initiatives.
As the network grew stronger, developed research, began engaging in advocacy activities at all levels and brought international attention to the issue, communities on the nearby Srepok River began seeking a similar network due to the cascade of dams that were being built upstream of the Srepok. Villages on the Srepok sought help from the Sesan network, and by 2005 formed their own network in Lumpait district and over thecourse of the next two years grew to encompass all 14 villages living along the Srepok in Ratanakiri province.
With the expansion of the network, SPN changed its name to the3S Rivers Protection Network (3SPN) and officially registered with the Ministry of Interior in late 2005. During this time, 3SPN also began to diversify its funding, in or order to help ensure long-term sustainability of the network. The network also began to engage in community fisheries management and conservation, community based research and a market information project. Management also changed in 2009, in order to reflect community ownership and indigenous leadership to the issue. The Coordinator and Team Leader, the highest management positions, came from local ethnic minority groups and grew up along the 3S rivers.
Over the years, 3SPN has continually worked towards becoming a community based organization and up to Dec 2013, 04 community basedorganizations have been established. As these CBOs develop mandates and clarify their roles and responsibilities, 3SPN plans to develop more CBOs in 2014, with the end goal of having 3SPN work primarily as asecretariat for these CBOs in the future.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
